intro: Thelypodium diehlii, commonly known as the Sierra Madre dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and herbaceous growth habit. The plant typically grows in rocky, arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and resemble those of a dandelion. Thelypodium diehlii plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for certain insects.
